scheduler.menu.schedule.allInOne
Class Progress

java.lang.Object
  javax.swing.SwingWorker<java.lang.Void,java.lang.Void>
      scheduler.menu.schedule.allInOne.Progress
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.lang.Runnable, java.util.concurrent.Future<java.lang.Void>, java.util.concurrent.RunnableFuture<java.lang.Void>
public class Progress
extends javax.swing.SwingWorker<java.lang.Void,java.lang.Void>

For displaying the progress of generation to the user with a nice progress bar. I don't completely understand the SwingWorker model, but the internet said I needed it. I'm reasonably sure the contents of this class are sound, but I did use some public fields to make things easier on myself. Beware. In particular, this class is the one that actually starts the "generate" process. In some magical way, it spawns the "generate" like a fork'd child and is able to update its progress as the child goes. The "generate" process is given this object so as to alter its progress as steps are completed.

Author:
Eric Liebowitz

Constructor Detail

Progress

public Progress(java.util.Vector<Course> cdb,
                java.util.Vector<Instructor> idb,
                java.util.Vector<Location> ldb,
                java.util.Vector<SchedulePreference> pdb)
Creates a progress bar whose total number of "thing to do" is equal to the number of course sections in the database. Every section scheduled with increment the progress of the bar by one "tick".

Parameters:
cdb - List of courses to generate with
idb - List of instructors to generate with
ldb - List of locations to generate with
pdb - List of schedule preferences to generate with
Method Detail

doInBackground

public java.lang.Void doInBackground()
I assume this does whatever I wanted to be done in the "background". IN this caes, that's the "generate" process

Specified by:
doInBackground in class javax.swing.SwingWorker<java.lang.Void,java.lang.Void>

done

protected void done()
What should happen when the "background" process (generating) end. The progress bar should dissappear.
